meaning: very ordinary, everyday
desc: Quotidian is a fancy way of saying "daily" or "ordinary." Quotidian events are the everyday details of life.
sentence: It affects quotidian lives of people.

meaning: irrelevant
sentence: That's quite slanderous remark I'd say.

meaning: being servant, being submissive
desc: Subservient means "compliant," "obedient," "submissive," or having the qualities of a servant. Something that's subservient has been made useful, or put into the service of, something else.
sentence: He was subservient to her because of her looks.

meaning: subservient to others to gain their favour, sycophant
sentence: He was being too lackey in front of officer.

meaning: financially weak, very poor
sentence: He lead his whole life in impecunious situations.

meaning: a happy occurrence
desc: If you find good things without looking for them, serendipity — unexpected good luck — has brought them to you.
sentence: That trip was surely a serendipity.

meaning: an unhappy occurrence
desc: When you talk of the vicissitudes of life, you're referring to the difficult times that we all go through: sickness, job loss, and other unwelcome episodes.
sentence: No one can escape vicissitudes of life.

meaning: lackadaisical,very inactive, apathetic
desc: To be listless is to be lethargic, low spirited, and limp.
sentence: That fever has made me listless in everything.

meaning: releasing of emotions
desc: Use the noun catharsis to refer to the experience a person can have of releasing emotional tension and feeling refreshed afterwards.
sentence: The dirge really was responsible for catharsis of daughter.

meaning: a religious lecture
desc: A homily is a sermon or religious speech offering encouragement or moral correction.
sentence: You are always welcome to the homily that we organize.

meaning: with evil intent
desc: Ominously is a word to describe how something threatening appears.
sentence: She laughed ominously.

meaning: paid of the debts
desc: To amortize is to gradually pay off a debt.
sentence: After long time, finally he was able to amortize his loan.

meaning: To flatter someone in order to gain favour, be lackey
sentence: The salesman inveigled her to get his product sold.

meaning: harbinger, signalling to start of some bad event
desc: A presage is a sign that something bad is about to happen
sentence: The riots are presage to a big revolution.

meaning: being very compatible and agreeable
sentence: Those two make indeed a simpatico couple.

meaning: to cause something, give rise to
desc: Engender is a fancy way of saying "to make happen".
sentence: The partiality of teacher engendered censure amongst students.

meaning: exculpate, to get free from guilt
desc: To exonerate someone is to declare him not guilty of criminal charges.
sentence: The man was finally exonerated after a long going case.

meaning: to satisfy
sentence: This small amount of money will not satiate this prodigal.

meaning: to mix something, make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
sentence: He was caught selling adulterated grains.

meaning: demarcate, to outline, to mark something clearly
desc: To delineate is to outline and define something in detail or with an actual marking of lines and boundaries.
sentence: The director was able to delineate the plot easily.

meaning: strong disapproval, harsh criticism
desc: Censure is a noun referring to very strong criticism; the verb means to criticize very strongly.
sentence: The public censured the new prime minister after his debunked scam.

meaning: to drop drastically
desc: The verb plummet means "to drop sharply"
sentence: The prices of stocks plummeted after the death of the CEO.

meaning: to imitate, to copy
desc: When you emulate someone, you imitate them, especially with the idea of matching their success.
sentence: You might emulate his clothing style, but you can't emulate his intelligence.

meaning: to run in order to not get caught, to flee
desc: Abscond is to escape, often taking something along.
sentence: The king absconded the kingdom overnight after general fomented the rebellion.

meaning: make believe with intent to deceive, behave unnaturally
desc: To dissemble is to hide under a false appearance, to deceive.
sentence: When confronted about their human rights record, the Chinese government typically dissembles.

meaning: to laugh at in contempt, to mock
desc: The verb deride means to speak to someone with contempt or show a low opinion of someone or something.
sentence: The sister used to deride his brother for his failures until one day when he became successful.

meaning: to appease, gain favor of, conciliate
desc: Propitiate means to appease someone or make them happy by doing a particular thing.
sentence: The company tried to propitiate the client after the blunder.

meaning: to pacify, to placate
sentence: The devotee tried to appease the goddess after that sin.

meaning: to applaud, to praise
sentence: The audience lauded his performance with lots of claps.

meaning: one who despises humanity
desc: A misanthrope is a person who hates or mistrusts other people.
sentence: Hitler was considered quite a misanthrope.

meaning: to give most importance to pleasures
desc: Strictly speaking, hedonism is the belief that pursuing pleasure leads to the greatest ethical good.
sentence: His art was mainly inspired from hedonism

meaning: a poem to praise or lament dead
desc: An elegy is a sad poem, usually written to praise and express sorrow for someone who is dead.
sentence: The elegy lead to the daughter's catharsis.

meaning: showing superficial interest in something but not actually knowing about it
desc: A dilettante is an amateur, often one who pretends to be very knowledgeable.
sentence: He was being a dilettante in music just to please her.

meaning: trickery through deception, artful, to artifice
desc: The tricky kind of deceit and manipulation is called chicanery.
sentence: The couple fell for the chicanery of the salesman then later they regretted it.

meaning: generosity, forgiving nature, munificence
desc: Magnanimous behavior is noble, generous, or unselfish, and to exhibit magnanimity is to be this way.
sentence: The king was known for his magnanimity.

meaning: false statement to defame someone
desc: Use the noun calumny to characterize verbal attacks that are meant to destroy reputations or friendships.
sentence: His ex spread lot of calumnies about him just to make his life miserable.

meaning: state of extreme dishonor (usually from public), obloquy, stigma
desc: If you go against or oppose what's good, you might earn opprobrium.
sentence: The company tried to placate the client after one of the manager put them into opprobrium.

meaning: an incorrect chronology, something out of its time
desc: An anachronism is something that doesn't fit its time period.
sentence: Considering the history being convoluted, its fine to have slight anachronism.

meaning: a persuasive speech, high-flown style of speaking
desc: Rhetoric is speaking or writing that's intended to persuade.
sentence: The crowd was almost convinced by his lucid rhetoric.

meaning: pertaining to supernatural things
sentence: My brother is always interested in these kind of occult practices.

meaning: honesty, integrity, credibility
sentence: Given his impeccable record, how can you have audacity to doubt his veracity.

meaning: regulation or dogma established by church; accepted rule, principal or works in a particular field
desc: Canon (one “n”) refers to a collection of rules or texts that are considered to be authoritative.
sentence: He truly abides by the canon of Indian Classical music.

meaning: one who considers one gender above other
sentence: Being a male chauvinistic, he always condescended women.

meaning: core of something, concise and full of meaning
desc: A pithy phrase or statement is brief but full of substance and meaning.
sentence: The conclusions need to be pithy.

meaning: worth giving respect, capable of being estimated
desc: Something or someone estimable is worthy of respect and admiration.
sentence: Though much more younger than his opponent, he was a estimable player.

meaning: a formality, daily routine, apathetic or unenthusiastic, careless
desc: Many of our everyday greetings are perfunctory. For example, when we say "Hello" and "How are you?", we usually do so out of habit.
sentence: I can't rely on his perfunctory search for travel places. He is never interested in going out.

meaning: amazing or wondrous, resembling prodigy, extraordinary in size
sentence: He surely would like to befriend that prodigious kid.

meaning: intellectually sound, shining, bright, well-lit, clear
sentence: She was amused by his luminous nature.

meaning: gullible, believing something easily
sentence: The freshers were too credulous to believe that the seniors were actually going to help them.

meaning: lacking a plan, enthusiasm, not connected to main subject, haphazard
desc: If you lack a definite plan or purpose and flit from one thing to another, your actions are desultory.
sentence: You can't crack any exam if you study in such desultory manner.

meaning: harmful, pernicious, anodyne, unfriendly
sentence: Her cousins act in very inimical way.

meaning: to replace something with other (usually by scheming or force), supersede
desc: Supplant means to take the place of.
sentence: The web series have supplanted the movies in today's times.

meaning: formally rescind, to disavow a formerly held belief, recant, retract
desc: Abjure is a more dramatic way to declare your rejection of something you once felt or believed.
sentence: Surprisingly, the witness of the case abjured his statement in the next hearing.

meaning: to draw out, put forth, evoke, provoke
desc: When you elicit, you're bringing out a response of some sort. A good comedian elicits a lot of laughs.
sentence: He clearly elicited the onerous consequences of the decision.

meaning: to restrict yourself (mostly from unhealthy or bad things), refrain
desc: If you abstain from something, you restrain yourself from consuming it.
sentence: I was so perturbed by that guy's condition that I have totally abstained from smoking.

meaning: to blame someone, to scold, upbraid, bring disgrace
desc: Reproach means to mildly criticize.
sentence: The old man always reproached his son for his misfortunes.

meaning: to undermine, weaken, assuage
sentence: The doctor reassured that though the drug has mild soporific effects, but it will alleviate the pain.

meaning: to prevent beforehand, to get rid off
desc: To obviate means to eliminate the need for something or to prevent something from happening.
sentence: The bonfire obviated any risks of wild animals attacking us in the jungle.

meaning: to refuse to pay, to reject as untrue, to disown
desc: To repudiate something is to reject it, or to refuse to accept or support it.
sentence: The insurance company repudiated my medical claim as it was not abiding by their terms and conditions.

meaning: to establish by proof, corroborate
desc: To substantiate is to give support to a claim.
sentence: His works clearly substantiated Newton's Laws of Motion.

meaning: to deceive using trickery
sentence: The salesman duped her into buying his product.

meaning: to penetrate, to pass through every part of
sentence: The air was occluded from one side of room, but could easily permeate from other side.

meaning: move back and forth, vacillate, indecisiveness
sentence: He oscillated between thoughts of taking Science or Commerce as major in school.

meaning: Something that quickly arouses anger, that has anger in it
sentence: He responded with such an irascible comment!

meaning: something that is very wordy, lengthy
desc: If you're verbose, you use far more words than you need to.
sentence: I don't like the author's verbose description of the character.

meaning: afraid, tremulous, full of fear, timid
desc: A timorous person is timid or shy, like your timorous friend who likes to hang out with close pals but gets nervous around big groups of new people.
sentence: That dog is very timorous because he always runs when he sees any human coming near him.

meaning: historical, old, antiquated
sentence: We can't apply archaic solutions to modern problems.

meaning: given exaggerated importance, pretentious
sentence: People were provoked by his bombastic speech on radicals.

meaning: showing off your scholar skills, meticulous
sentence: Students were apathetic to his pedantic lectures.

meaning: assuming things, being impertinently bold
desc: When someone takes liberties, doing things too boldly, you can describe them with the adjective presumptuous.
sentence: She was fed up with his presumptuous gestures.

meaning: relating to typical rural life, pastoral
sentence: Though he shifted to a new city, his behaviour was still bucolic.

meaning: very ordinary, relating to common people
sentence: His art was not at all quotidian.

meaning: relevant, related to context, significant
sentence: You can't shut him up! He is providing germane insights.

meaning: erroneous, having errors
sentence: His theory is fallacious.

meaning: lacking social skills, ill mannered
sentence: Its very gauche to laugh on someone's funeral.

meaning: persistent, adamant, intransigent, inflexible
sentence: He is very obstinate in not inviting his mother on his wedding.

meaning: properly set up in a particular field, being veteran
sentence: He is an inveterate gambler.

meaning: art of writing and producing plays
sentence: His dramaturgy is commendable

meaning: gadget useful for a particular job, a deceitful scheme contrived to evade
sentence: his testimony was just a contrivance to throw us off the track

meaning: theatrical performance
scornful/mocking, disdainfully humorous
sentence: His sardonic laughter was rather irascible.

meaning: harmful to living beings, pernicious
sentence: These kind of fruits are truly deleterious for us.

meaning: a tiny piece of anything
collection of people
simultaneous discharge of firearms, sudden outburst
optimistic cheerful, accompanied by bloodshed, slaughterous
conspicuously and offensively loud
sentence: He was speaking so vociferously, that whole restaurant started gazing him.
